title: Apple pulls HomePod update after falling victim to a similar glitch that BRICKED Google Home
text:
Apple is pulling a new software update for its smart speaker, the HomePod, after it started rendering the devices unusable.

According to various HomePod owners, who took to MacRumors' forums this week to report problems with their devices, a glitch occurred following the introduction of Apple's iOS 13.2 update.

Once downloaded, users say their device gets stuck in an endless loop of restarting, while others say the device becomes completely unresponsive.

Apple's Homepod has encountered an update issue that is rendering the device unusable. The company has since pulled the most recent version of the software (File photo)

Apple has yet to publicly acknowledge those problems being reporter by users and MailOnline's request for comment has not been returned before time of publication.

According to MacRumors, Apple has pulled its software update and is now recommending that users refrain from resetting the device or removing it from the Home app.

News of a potential update glitch follows a similar saga experienced by users of Google's smart speaker, the Google Home.

Last week many users of Google's smart speaker reported critical issues with the speaker following a firmware update.

The glitch similarly rendered the device unusable, causing the speaker to go unresponsive even after returning to factor settings.

Google has also encountered similar problems and is now offering to replace Google Home speakers that were bricked by a firmware update (File photo)

Google has since promised to replace any device affected by the issues regardless of whether it falls under warranty and has promised to roll out a fix for the problem soon.

For Apple, the HomePod glitch marks yet another bump in the road since iOS 13 was unveiled last month.

The tech giant has already released two subsequent updates - iOS 13.1 and 13.2 - since the operating system was unveiled on September 19.
description: Various HomePod owners took to MacRumors' forums this week to report problems with their devices, a glitch occurred following the introduction of Apple's iOS 13.2 update.
